Mr Heng directed Chua to handle the matter and to ensure that the fines in relation to the charges were paid.
The document also contained the logo of the State Courts, a payment reference number and a case number.
In her submissions, Deputy Public Prosecutor Melina Chew said the evidence that showed Chua knew the document was false included the fact that there was no court mention for Mr Heng that day.
She said Chua's claim that he went to court on April 16, 2019, to plead guilty on behalf of Mr Heng and pay the fine is a deliberate lie.
But she added that it was unclear why he lied to his employer.
A police report was lodged on behalf of the Registrar of the State Courts on June 10, 2019, stating that the State Courts had reason to believe that the document bearing its logo was forged.
At the pre-trial conference on July 3, 2019, on the application of the LTA, Mr Heng was granted a discharge amounting to an acquittal for his charges.
For using as genuine a forged document, Chua could have been jailed for up to four years, fined or both.

documents.title: Man gets jail for using forged State Courts payment slip to claim traffic fines were paid for his boss

sentences.content: SINGAPORE: A man claimed he had helped his boss pay his traffic fines in court, handing his boss a forged payment slip with the State Courts logo on it as proof.
In reality, he had gone to court for his own case and a warrant of arrest was later issued for his boss, who was a no-show.
Chua Chee Siang, 42, claimed trial to one count of using a forged document as genuine in a case the prosecution called "ridiculous".
He was convicted last month and sentenced on Tuesday (Sep 20) to two months' jail.
According to court documents, Chua was working as an administrator for Mr Heng Cheng Hock, the director of A-TEC Motorz at the time of the offence.
In February 2019, Mr Heng was charged in the State Courts in his capacity as director of A-TEC Motorz for various traffic offences.
He directed Chua to handle the matter and ensure that the fines for the charges were paid.
However, Chua did not settle the case with the Land Transport Authority (LTA).
A warrant of arrest was issued for Mr Heng when he did not show up for his court case, and when Mr Heng learned of this, he demanded documentary proof from Chua that the case had been settled.
On May 10 2019, Chua handed Mr Heng a payment advice chit dated Apr 16, 2019.
The document contained the logo of the State Courts and stated that a court fine of S$300 imposed by Court 25 had been paid.
Mr Heng went to court on May 28, 2019 and presented the document Chua had handed him.
However, discrepancies were noted in the slip and investigations were mounted.
The document was found to be forged.
At trial, Chua claimed that he had gone to court on Apr 16, 2019, to plead guilty on behalf of his boss and pay the fine of S$300 imposed by the court.

"Curiously, the accused has persistently maintained this claim, from the outset when his police statements were recorded, all the way till the end of trial," said Deputy Public Prosecutor Melina Chew.
This was despite the fact that it was not possible for Chua to plead guilty on behalf of his boss.

Even though his boss was mistaken in directing Chua to attend court on his behalf, if Chua did go to court to represent Mr Heng, the court would have refused to accept the plea and asked Mr Heng to attend court himself.
Second, it is not possible for the court to sentence an offender when a warrant of arrest is active against them.
A warrant of arrest was issued against Mr Heng on Mar 5, 2019 because he had not attended his case.
This means there was no fine levied by the court for Mr Heng.
Mr Heng later paid a composition sum of S$250 for his charges and was granted a discharge amounting to an acquittal by LTA.

The State Courts' internal finance management system showed that the payment reference number on the forged payment chit Chua obtained was for a case involving another man, where a fine of S$700 was imposed by Court 14.
"Further, a payment advice chit only serves to advise an offender on the fine amount which they are supposed to pay and does not serve as proof of payment of a fine," said the prosecutor.
She said that Chua did go to court on Apr 16, 2019, but it was for his own LTA case.

"For exact reasons that would remain only known to the accused, the accused decided to lie to (Mr) Heng and tell him that his LTA case had been settled, when in fact it was not and there was an active warrant to arrest for (Mr) Heng," said Ms Chew.
She quoted Chua's claim that "the amount of S$300 ... to do such a thing is definitely ridiculous".
"The evidence presented before this honourable court, however, leads to the inevitable conclusion that the accused did do the 'ridiculous'," she said.

She said the nature of the forgery showed that the chit could not have been issued due to an oversight or administrative error and slammed the underlying suggestions that an officer of the State Courts would have engaged in forgery.
Ms Chew had asked for about three months' jail, noting Chua's lack of remorse as evident from his "fanciful defence".
He was allowed to defer his sentence to October.
For using a forged document as genuine, he could have been jailed for up to four years, fined, or both.

silver_truth: In Singapore, a 42-year-old man named Chua Chee Siang was sentenced to two months' jail on September 20, 2022, for using a forged document as genuine. The case stemmed from February 2019 when Mr. Heng Cheng Hock, the director of A-TEC Motorz, was charged under the Road Traffic Act. Mr. Heng directed Chua, his administrator, to handle the fines related to the charges. However, Chua failed to settle the case with the Land Transport Authority (LTA), leading to a warrant of arrest for Mr. Heng. Chua then handed Mr. Heng a forged payment slip dated April 16, 2019, falsely claiming he had paid the fine on his boss's behalf. Discrepancies in the slip were noted when Mr. Heng presented it in court on May 28, 2019, prompting an investigation that revealed the document was forged. Despite Chua's persistent claims that he had gone to court to plead guilty on behalf of Mr. Heng, evidence showed he went for his own LTA case. The court found that it was impossible for Chua to represent Mr. Heng, especially with an active warrant against him. Mr. Heng eventually paid a composition sum of S$250 and was acquitted by LTA. Chua's lack of remorse and the deliberate nature of the forgery led the prosecution to call his defense "ridiculous." Chua was allowed to defer his sentence to October.

documents.title: 日本自民党要求党员和"统一教"断绝一切关系 近期将公布"关系密切"人名

sentences.content: 日本自民党干事长茂木敏充（日本电视台）
海外网8月31日电 据日本电视台8月31日消息，日本自民党干事长茂木敏充当天表示，从今以后，要求自民党所属的国会议员和“统一教”断绝一切关系，自民党将以此作为基本方针贯彻实施。
茂木敏充称，若发现有国会议员未遵守要求，他将不能参与自民党内任何活动。茂木敏充还表示，近期将公布和“统一教”有密切关系的议员名单。
日本共同社8月中旬对712名国会议员进行了调查，根据统计结果，其中106名议员与“统一教”存在关联，他们或参加过教会活动，或在选举中接受过教会支持。日媒认为，包括内阁成员在内的自民党议员们与“统一教”关系的接连曝光，正是日本政府支持率下滑的原因之一。

documents.title: Japan's LDP to update list of members linked to Unification Church

sentences.content: TOKYO - Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) will release an updated list of members who have had connections with the controversial Unification Church, its secretary-general Toshimitsu Motegi said on Tuesday.
Links between the church and LDP have been in focus after former premier Shinzo Abe was shot during an election rally.
The suspected killer blamed him for supporting the church, which he said had bankrupted his mother.
The church has declined to comment on her donations and has also said it no longer accepts donations that cause financial hardship.
The LDP this month said that 179 out of 379 members it surveyed were found to have interacted with the church.
In a Cabinet reshuffle last month, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida removed seven ministers who had disclosed connections to the church in an attempt to reverse a slide in his approval ratings.
However on Tuesday, Economy Minister Daishiro Yamagiwa admitted in a news conference he had attended a Unification Church-sponsored event in 2018 that he had not previously reported to the party.
Asked whether he would consider stepping down as minister, Mr Yamagiwa said he would take responsibility by staying on as minister and carrying out the administration's economic stimulus measures.
"This is the work I need to fulfil," he added.

Amid increasing public scrutiny into the party's relationship with the church, the Cabinet's approval rating has plunged to around 30 per cent in recent polls compared with a peak of around 60 per cent earlier this year.
The low ratings are close to what political analysts see as a danger level beyond which Japanese prime ministers may find it difficult to carry out their agenda.
REUTERS

silver_truth: On August 31, 2022, Japan's Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) secretary-general Toshimitsu Motegi announced that all LDP lawmakers must cut ties with the controversial Unification Church. This decision comes amid increasing scrutiny and a drop in the government's approval ratings, which have plunged to around 30 percent due to revelations of connections between LDP members and the church. A recent survey by Japan's Kyodo News found that 106 out of 712 lawmakers had associations with the church, and an LDP internal survey revealed 179 out of 379 members had interacted with the church. The scrutiny intensified following the assassination of former premier Shinzo Abe, whose suspected killer blamed him for supporting the church, which had allegedly bankrupted his mother. In response to the scandal, Prime Minister Fumio Kishida reshuffled his cabinet last month, removing seven ministers with church ties. Despite these efforts, Economy Minister Daishiro Yamagiwa admitted on September 20, 2022, that he had attended a church event in 2018, which he had not previously disclosed. Amid the ongoing controversy, public dissatisfaction with Kishida’s handling of the issue is high, with nearly two-thirds of respondents in a recent Jiji news agency survey expressing disapproval.

documents.title: NEA minta maklum balas berkait deposit 10-20 sen bagi minuman dalam tin dan botol plastik

sentences.content: SINGAPURA: Mulai pertengahan 2024, para pembeli mungkin harus membayar tambahan 10 atau 20 sen sebagai deposit bagi minuman dalam tin atau botol plastik. Ini tambahan kepada harga runcit dan boleh diperolehi kembali jika mereka memulangkan tin atau botol plastik tersebut ke tempat pemulangan seperti pasar raya, menurut Agensi Sekitaran Kebangsaan (NEA) hari ini (20 Sep).

NEA meminta maklum balas awam mengenai cadangan tersebut, yang bertujuan untuk menaikkan kadar kitar semula, mengurangkan pembaziran dan menurunkan pengeluaran karbon sebagai sebahagian daripada usaha untuk menangani perubahan iklim.

Skim tersebut akan menyumbang kepada sasaran yang ditetapkan Singapura di bawah Pelan Singapura Menghijau 2030 dan Pelan Induk Tanpa Sisa untuk mengurangkan 20 peratus sisa yang dihantar ke tapak pelupusan sampah per kapita setiap hari menjelang 2026 dan 30 peratus menjelang 2030 serta menaikkan kadar kitar semula nasional kepada 70 peratus menjelang 2030.
Agensi itu menyatakan dalam satu kenyataan hari ini: "Dengan deposit ditetapkan, skim ini akan menggalak pembeli untuk memulangkan bekas air mereka yang sudah kosong."

Semua bekas tin dan plastik yang mengandungi minuman seperti tin minuman, jus buah-buahan dan air putih akan dikenakan deposit semasa pembelian. Sebagai contoh, air tin yang dijual pada harga S$1 akan dikenakan bayaran S$1.10 semasa pembelian, jika jumlah deposit 10 sen.

Harga deposit akan ditetapkan bagi semua bekas yang boleh menampung antara 150ml dengan tiga liter cecair. Bungkusan minuman yang diperbuat daripada bahan Tetra Pak tidak akan dikenakan deposit buat masa ini.

Untuk mendapat deposit mereka kembali, pembeli harus mengembalikan bekas minuman yang sudah kosong dan tidak dicuci ke tempat yang ditetapkan. Mereka boleh melakukan perkara tersebut di kaunter juruwang atau mesin layan diri.
Bekas-bekas tersebut akan dikitar semula.
Di bawah cadangan NEA, semua pasar raya yang mempunyai keluasan lebih 200 meter persegi, yang kini sebanyak 400 pasar raya, akan menyediakan tempat untuk memulangkan bekas minuman.
NEA juga merancang untuk mengadakan tempat memulangkan bekas minuman di gerai-gerai, kedai makan dan pusat beli-belah.
Untuk membantu para pembeli mengenal pasti bekas yang boleh dikitar semula, skim itu menyarankan agar bungkusan yang layak dikitar semula diletakkan "tanda deposit".
Kod bar (barcode) bagi minuman yang sudah dibungkus terlebih dahulu mesti didaftarkan dengan pengendali skim supaya mesin layan diri dapat mengenal pasti bekas yang boleh dikitar semula.
Cadangan itu memerlukan pengendali skim untuk "diterajui industri" kerana ia dapat mengurangkan kos dan juga menggalak kebertanggungjawapan dan kecekapan. Skim itu juga bukan untuk keuntungan.

Pengendali skim harus mencapai sasaran sekurang-kurangnya 80 peratus kadar pemulangan dan memberi laporan kepada NEA setiap tahun mengenai operasi dan prestasi mereka. Agensi itu akan mengawal dan memantau sama ada pengeluar minuman mematuhi skim tersebut.

Tempoh peralihan akan diadakan selepas tempoh pelaksanaan supaya pengeluar minuman dan penjual dapat menghabiskan bekalan sedia ada untuk memastikan air minuman yang dijual nanti akan ada ciri yang ditetapkan seperti seperti tanda deposit.

documents.title: Harga minuman dalam tin mungkin naik bawah skim kitar semula baru

sentences.content: AGENSI Sekitaran Kebangsaan (NEA) berkata minuman dalam tin atau botol mungkin dilabelkan dengan tanda deposit dan pelanggan boleh menuntut bayaran balik deposit apabila mereka memulangkan bekas minuman kosong mereka ke tempat pemulangan.
Apabila memulangkan bekas minuman kosong itu, mereka boleh menebus deposit dalam bentuk tunai atau pemindahan digital.
Tempat memulangkan bekas minuman itu akan disediakan di semua pasar raya lebih besar daripada 200 meter persegi.
Tempat-tempat ini mungkin adalah dalam bentuk mesin layan diri di mana botol dan tin itu boleh dimasukkan untuk mendapatkan wang, atau kaunter yang dikendalikan secara manual.
NEA mengatakan apabila ia dilancarkan, akan terdapat lebih 400 tempat pemulangan.
Ini meningkat daripada 50 mesin layan diri yang beroperasi sekarang.
Lokasi lain termasuk kedai serbaneka dan pusat masyarakat.

documents.title: 料2024年中起 公众购买包装饮料须付押金 退还容器时可退费

sentences.content: （早报讯）我国有意最迟在2024年中落实饮料瓶罐退费制，到时公众购买预先包装饮料时得支付1角或2角的押金，并可在退还空容器时取回押金。
上述计划预料将涵盖所有预先包装饮料，例如汽水、果汁、牛奶、啤酒及矿泉水等，这将包括所有150毫升至3公升的铝罐和塑料瓶饮料，但暂时不会涵盖纸盒装和玻璃瓶装饮料。
我国所制造的住家垃圾中，约三分之一是包装垃圾，其中六成属于塑料垃圾。去年，仅6%的塑料垃圾被回收再循环使用。为了降低送往埋置厂的垃圾数量，提高全国回收率，国家环境局计划最迟在2024年中实行饮料瓶罐退费制（Beverage Container Return Scheme）。
环境局星期二（9月20日）发文告宣布，为饮料瓶罐退费制展开为期约一个月的公众咨询活动。过去两年多来，当局广泛咨询了饮料生产商、零售业者及非政府组织等利益相关者的意见，为这项计划共同制定框架。
根据拟议中的饮料瓶罐退费制，公众购买预先包装饮料时须支付1角或2角的押金，日后到指定回收站退回空容器时，便可取回押金。为了方便公众及确保计划易于管理，无论饮料容器的大小和材料，所有瓶罐的押金额都将划一。
此外，所有包含在计划下的饮料瓶罐都会附上押金标签（deposit mark），以协助消费者辨别哪些饮料须支付押金。
有意规定大型超市须设有瓶罐回收站
为便于公众退还饮料瓶罐及取回押金，环境局有意规定所有面积超过200平方米的大型超市须设有瓶罐回收站，这包括设立柜台或安装反向贩卖机（reverse vending machine），让消费者退回空容器。当局也有意在邻里场所如民众俱乐部、便利店、住宅区的公共空间、小贩中心和食阁及商场等设立回收站。
至于如何取回押金，消费者可选择通过电子转账，例如PayNow或直接转入易通卡或NETS万捷通卡（Flashpay）等，也可选择现金或现金券等退费方式。
环境局指出，目前全世界有约50个地方包括挪威、德国、克罗地亚及澳大利亚新南威尔士州和西澳等已实行类似计划，并且证实有助显著推高饮料瓶罐的回收率。
本地估计每年向市场供应超过10亿个包装饮料，根据外国落实这项计划的经验，环境局估计以后会有多达80％的饮料瓶罐会退还回收。
永续发展与环境部兼交通部高级政务部长许连碹博士说：“饮料瓶罐退费制有潜能可以显著提高我们的饮料容器回收率。这将使新加坡管理包装垃圾的方式向前迈进一步。”
公众即日起至10月14日，可上网提供有关饮料瓶罐退费制的反馈。

documents.title: S’pore could charge 10 to 20 cents more per canned or bottled drink under proposed recycling scheme

sentences.content: SINGAPORE - By mid-2024, consumers seeking to quench their thirst from a canned or bottled drink will likely have to fork out 10 to 20 cents more.
However, this extra cost can be redeemed if consumers return their empty bottles and cans for recycling at any of the beverage container return points islandwide.
These return points could take the form of "reverse" vending machines, into which bottles and cans can be deposited to get money in return, or manned counters.
By the time of implementation, there will be more than 400 such points on the island, up from the 50 reverse vending machines currently.
The new beverage container return scheme proposed by the National Environment Agency (NEA) was announced on Tuesday.
Under the proposed scheme, a small deposit of between 10 cents and 20 cents will be added to the price of all pre-packaged drinks in plastic bottles and metal cans between 150ml and 3 litres.
This deposit will be the same across all beverages of the same size.
Drinks will be labelled with a deposit mark and consumers can claim a refund of the deposits when they return their empty beverage containers to a return point.
This redemption will likely be in the form of cash or digital transfer.
Return points will be set up at all supermarkets that are larger than 200 sq m. Other possible return locations include convenience stores and community centres.
The proposed scheme comes after extensive public engagement and aims to increase the recycling rate of beverage containers in Singapore to 80 per cent.
This is NEA's latest idea to nudge people towards recycling, as only 6 per cent of all plastic waste was recycled in Singapore last year.
Many nations which have implemented such a scheme have been able to raise their recycling rates of beverage containers substantially.
For example, in Germany, the recycling rate of beverage containers stands at 98 per cent.
NEA is seeking feedback on the beverage container return scheme, which is part of governmental recommendations to cut such packaging waste generated in Singapore.
Drink producers and retailers will be charged a fee by a non-profit administrator of the scheme for each drink manufactured or imported.
When consumers return the containers, the administrator will aggregate them and facilitate their sale to waste companies.
The revenue from this sale will be used to reimburse producers and retailers for the extra costs incurred.
Hence, the total amount reimbursed to the drink producers will depend on how effective they have been in encouraging their customers to recycle the containers.

NEA said the beverage container return scheme marks the first phase of the Extended Producer Responsibility system introduced to vest producers with greater responsibility in ensuring their products are recycled.
Such a scheme would promote accountability and efficiency in the industry and also minimise costs to run the scheme, said NEA.
Ms Kathlyn Tan, a member of the work group that suggested the beverage container return initiative to NEA, said the 10-cent to 20-cent deposit amount is a good start.

Ms Tan, the director of Rumah Group, a family office for sustainable investments, said: "My hope for the scheme is that our recycling rates will be increased; we become more conscious of our environmental footprint; and that negative impacts on the vulnerable will be minimised."
Public feedback is sought on the deposit amount, where the refund points should be and how the deposit should be refunded, among other things.
Feedback can be given at Reach, the Government's feedback unit, from now to Oct 14 at this website.
Correction note: The headline for this story has been updated to indicate that the recycling scheme is still undergoing consultation.

documents.title: Consumers of pre-packaged drinks may have to pay 10-20 cent deposit under proposed recycling scheme

sentences.content: Consumers will, however, be able to get their 20 cents back upon returning the can to designated return points that have yet to be confirmed.
The proposed beverage container return scheme is currently in its consultation phase.
After details are firmed up, the scheme will likely be rolled out by mid-2024, with a grace period for producers to ensure that pre-packaged beverages comply with the new packaging requirements.

The goal, under the Singapore Green Plan 2030 and the Zero Waste Masterplan, is to reduce the amount of waste sent to the landfill per capita per day by 20 per cent by 2026, and 30 per cent by 2030, and to increase the national recycling rate to 70 per cent by 2030.
Singapore's scheme takes reference from similar programmes under different names in around 50 other jurisdictions.
To avoid confusion, all beverages - including alcohol and dairy products - that come in metal cans and plastic bottles will be eligible.
The scheme will likely be managed by a not-for-profit entity that will take charge of operations, such as the collection of used containers, and the handling of deposits.
Barcodes of pre-packaged drinks must be registered with the operator.
This helps the operator track the numbers and types of containers covered and also serves to prevent consumers from claiming a refund for inapplicable containers, such as those bought overseas.
Barcodes can also be scanned when returned to reverse vending machines.

As to where the containers can be returned, the Government is mulling mandated return points at large supermarkets with a total area of more than 200 sq m. These supermarkets - of which there are around 400 - are also the preferred return locations for survey respondents.
Return points could take the form of over-the-counter manual returns handled by cashiers, or automated reverse vending machines.
The scheme operator will pay these return points handling fees to compensate for associated costs.

silver_truth: On September 20, 2022, the National Environment Agency (NEA) of Singapore announced a proposed beverage container return scheme set to be implemented by mid-2024. Under this scheme, consumers will pay an additional deposit of 10 to 20 cents on pre-packaged drinks in plastic bottles and metal cans ranging from 150ml to 3 litres. This deposit can be reclaimed upon returning the empty containers to designated return points, which will include over 400 locations such as large supermarkets, convenience stores, and community centres.

documents.title: Parlimen Indonesia lulus RUU perlindungan data peribadi

sentences.content: JAKARTA: Parlimen Indonesia semalam meluluskan rang undang-undang (RUU) bagi perlindungan data peribadi, yang meliputi denda korporat dan hukuman penjara hingga enam tahun untuk kesalahan berkait pengendalian data di negara ini.
Kelulusan RUU itu menyusul selepas berlaku siri kebocoran data dan siasatan dijalankan terhadap dakwaan insiden membabitkan institusi serta firma kerajaan di Indonesia.
Ia meliputi syarikat insurans, syarikat telekomunikasi dan utiliti awam, malah aplikasi pengesanan kontak COVID-19 yang mendedahkan rekod vaksinasi Presiden Joko Widodo.
Rata-rata Ahli Parlimen menyokong RUU itu yang diusahakan sejak 2016.

Ia antara lain memberi kuasa kepada Presiden untuk membentuk sebuah badan pengawal selia bagi mendenda pengendali data yang melanggar undang-undang berhubung pengedaran atau pengumpulan data peribadi.
Kadar denda tertinggi ialah dua peratus daripada pendapatan tahunan sesebuah syarikat, dan aset mereka boleh dirampas atau dilelong.
Undang-undang itu merangkumi tempoh 'pelarasan' selama dua tahun, namun tidak menggariskan secara khusus bagaimana pelanggaran akan ditangani ketika fasa berkenaan.

Selain itu, individu boleh dihukum penjara hingga enam tahun atas kesalahan memalsukan data peribadi untuk kepentingan peribadi, atau penjara hingga lima tahun bagi kesalahan mengumpul data peribadi secara haram.
Pengguna pula berhak mendapat pampasan atas pelanggaran data mereka, serta menarik balik kebenaran penggunaan data mereka.
Menteri Komunikasi Indonesia, Johnny G Plate, berkata kelulusan RUU terbabit 'menandakan era baharu dalam pengurusan data peribadi di Indonesia.'
"Salah satu kewajipan pengendali data elektronik, sama ada awam mahupun swasta, ialah memastikan data peribadi dalam sistem mereka dilindungi," katanya kepada pemberita.
Ahli Parlimen, Nico Siahaan, memaklumkan undang-undang itu akan turut memudahkan pemindahan data antara Indonesia dengan negara yang mempunyai perundangan serupa. - REUTERS

documents.title: Indonesia Parliament passes long-awaited data protection law

sentences.content: Under the new law, a body that reports to the President will be set up to formulate policies pertaining to personal data protection, oversee their implementation, and punish data handlers for breaking rules on personal data collection or distribution.
Communication and Informatics Minister Johnny Plate said the passage of the Bill marked the start of “a new era in the management of personal data of the public, especially in the digital sphere”.
Indonesia is the fifth South-east Asian country to have a specific law on personal data protection, after Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and the Philippines.
The new law will push government institutions as well as companies to improve their cyber security, experts said.
Information technology security has yet to become a priority in the development of Indonesia’s electronic systems, digital forensic expert Ruby Alamsyah told The Straits Times.

And in the event of a data leak, all electronic system providers - both government and private entities - continue with their operations without conducting proper probes and going through legal processes.

documents.title: Indonesia parliament passes long-awaited data protection Bill

sentences.content: JAKARTA: Indonesia's parliament passed into law on Tuesday (Sep 20) a personal data protection Bill that includes corporate fines and up to six years imprisonment for those found to have mishandled data in the world's fourth most populous country.

The Bill's passage comes after a series of data leaks and probes into alleged breaches at government firms and institutions in Indonesia, from a state insurer, telecoms company and public utility to a contact-tracing COVID-19 app that revealed President Joko Widodo's vaccine records.
Lawmakers overwhelmingly approved the Bill, which authorises the president to form an oversight body to fine data handlers for breaching rules on distributing or gathering personal data.
The biggest fine is 2 per cent of a corporation's annual revenue and could see their assets confiscated or auctioned off.
The law includes a two-year "adjustment" period, but does not specify how violations would be addressed during that phase.
The legislation stipulates individuals can be jailed for up to six years for falsifying personal data for personal gain or up to five years for gathering personal data illegally.
Users are entitled to compensation for data breaches and can withdraw consent to use their data.
Communications minister, Johnny G Plate, said the Bill's passage "marks a new era in the management of personal data in Indonesia, especially on the digital front."
Abdul Kharis Almasyhari, a member of the commission overseeing the law, said it would mean the state was ensuring protection of the personal data of its people.
The law has been in the works since 2016 and was held up by debate about financial penalties and control of the oversight body, lawmakers said.
Authorities have said the law was based on the European Union legislation.
Satriyo Wibowo, a data protection expert who was consulted during its drafting, said it would force companies to improve their data protection.

However, Wahyudi Djafar, who researches data protection for the Institute for Policy Research and Advocacy, questioned whether the penalties were strict enough to force government bodies to improve their data handling.

silver_truth: On September 20, 2022, Indonesia's parliament passed a significant personal data protection Bill, marking a new era in the management of personal data in the country. The legislation includes corporate fines and imprisonment of up to six years for mishandling data. This move follows a series of data breaches and investigations involving government institutions and private firms, including a state insurer, a telecom company, a public utility, and a COVID-19 contact-tracing app that exposed President Joko Widodo's vaccination records. The Bill, supported overwhelmingly by lawmakers, authorizes the President to establish an oversight body to enforce the rules, with potential fines reaching 2% of a corporation's annual revenue and the possibility of asset confiscation or auction. The law, which has been in development since 2016, also includes a two-year adjustment period and aims to enhance cyber security among government and private entities. Communications Minister Johnny G Plate highlighted that the Bill ushers in a new era for personal data management in Indonesia, particularly in the digital domain. Experts believe the legislation will push institutions to prioritize data protection, though some, like Wahyudi Djafar from the Institute for Policy Research and Advocacy, question if the penalties are stringent enough. The law draws inspiration from European Union regulations and positions Indonesia as the fifth Southeast Asian nation to enact specific personal data protection laws, following Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, and the Philippines.

documents.title: 新能源车领域遭拜登背刺后，韩国总理：美国似乎是违反了规定

sentences.content: （观察者网讯）美国拜登政府日前颁布的《通胀削减法案》因将韩国产电动汽车排除在税收抵免对象之外，成为韩美之间的外交争论焦点。
据韩联社9月20日报道，韩国国务总理韩德洙20日表示，从法理角度研判，美国政府歧视韩产电动汽车之举有违韩美自贸协定中有关最惠国待遇的规定。但他也表示，应先寻求其他方法，而把从违反自贸协定有关规定层面入手解决问题当作最后手段。
据报道，韩德洙当天出席韩国国会问政会时表示，从法理角度对美方举措进行分析的结果显示，美方似乎是违反了有关规定，“但根据有关规定针对美方采取相应措施耗时较长，我们应先寻求其他方法，而把从违反自贸协定有关规定层面入手解决问题当作最后手段比较可取。”
值得一提的是，当地时间19日，韩国总统尹锡悦抵达纽约，开启为期四天的访美之旅。
路透社也指出，韩国反对美国对电动汽车补贴的新规定，这将令尹锡悦首次正式访美之旅蒙上阴影，并扰乱最近韩美联盟的实力展示。
9月20日，路透社以“电动汽车之争令韩总统首次访美蒙上阴影”为题发表文章9月20日，路透社以“电动汽车之争令韩总统首次访美蒙上阴影”为题发表文章
路透社20日报道称，访美期间，尹锡悦将与美国总统拜登举行峰会，预计两位领导人将谈及韩国对拜登上个月签署的《通胀削减法案》的担忧。此前，首尔官员曾要求华盛顿将关于电动汽车补贴的新规定推迟到2025年，现代汽车完成其在佐治亚州建厂的计划后再加以实施，尹锡悦可能会在与拜登的峰会上重申这一要求。
据报道，当被问及《通胀削减法案》时，韩国总统府经济首席秘书崔相穆（Choi Sang-mok）表示，双方尚未确定峰会议程，但可以根据其重要性讨论该问题。
当地时间8月16日，美国总统拜登签署《通胀削减法案》。根据该法案，美国将向购买二手电动汽车的本国消费者提供4000美元的税收抵免，向购买新电动汽车的消费者提供7500美元税收抵免。但享受两项补贴的前提是，其购买的车辆“须在北美组装且从与美国签署自由贸易协定（FTA）的国家采购超过一定比例的电池材料或零部件”。由于现代等韩国主要汽车品牌在美国没有电动汽车工厂，这项规定将使这些韩企处于不利地位。
据观察者网此前报道，首尔一名高级官员曾表示，韩国将这一新规则视为“背叛”，“可能会感觉像被人从背后刺了一刀”，这有可能导致韩美这一亲密盟友之间的经济和安全合作复杂化。
此前，彭博社等外媒报道曾将此事与上月尹锡悦未与访韩的佩洛西会面联系起来。报道援引知情人士的话称，尹锡悦犯了一个“致命错误”，上个月佩洛西访问韩国时，尹锡悦未与其举行面对面会议，而这样的会议可能会提供一个至关重要的机会，能够在《通胀削减法案》通过之前寻求对其做出改变。对此，韩德洙20日在国会上也做出了回应。
韩德洙称，据他了解，韩方当时充分照顾到美方，且提前与佩洛西方面进行了沟通。当时韩国总统正在休假，但因为多人建议，韩美双方决定安排通电话，由此促成尹锡悦与佩洛西长达30分钟的通话。就美国《通胀削减法》对韩产电动汽车不利是受到了“韩方怠慢佩洛西”的影响的说法，韩德洙称，两者没有关联，因为佩洛西访韩时有关法案尚未获得参议院通过，并没有受到太大关注。
据路透社报道，最近几周，一些韩国高级官员已经动员起来，向美国官员转达他们的担忧并寻求豁免，但解决方案还远未明确。韩国产业通商资源部20日表示，产业部长官李昌洋将访问美国，同美国对口部门高层就美国《通胀削减法案》等交换意见。
本月初，美国国家安全顾问沙利文曾对韩国国家安保室室长金圣翰（Kim Sung-han）称，《通胀削减法案》对韩国来说“利多于弊”，但也承诺审查新规则的影响。
一名匿名的韩国高级官员则表示，“它在结构上相当复杂，因为它已经签署成为法律，但有办法解决它”。

documents.title: Row over EV subsidy rules overshadows S. Korean president's first US visit

sentences.content: SEOUL - South Korea's opposition to new rules governing US subsidies for electric vehicles will overshadow President Yoon Suk-yeol's first official trip to the United States, disrupting a recent display of alliance strength with Washington.
Mr Yoon, who was in London for the funeral of Queen Elizabeth, departed for New York late Monday to attend the United Nations General Assembly.
He will fly to Canada on Thursday for the last leg of his trip before returning home on Saturday.

In New York, Mr Yoon will hold a summit with US President Joe Biden where both leaders are expected to discuss North Korea's growing weapons threats and mounting concerns in South Korea over the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), signed by Mr Biden last month.

The new law eliminates federal tax credits for electric vehicles (EVs) made outside North America, meaning companies like Hyundai Motor and its affiliate Kia will no longer be eligible for such subsidies.

The law has sparked complaints from government officials in Seoul, who see it as a betrayal of Mr Biden's vows to boost bilateral economic ties after South Korean companies agreed to make major investments and build factories in the US.
Seoul officials have said the law may violate a bilateral free trade agreement, and they have asked Washington to postpone the new rules until Hyundai completes building its Georgia factory in 2025.
Mr Yoon is likely to reiterate that request during the upcoming summit.
A number of high-level South Korean officials have been mobilised in recent weeks to relay concerns to their US counterparts and press for exemptions, though solutions are far from clear.

US national security adviser Jake Sullivan told his South Korean counterpart Kim Sung Han early this month that the IRA would bring "more pluses than minuses" to South Korea but promised to review the impact of the new rules.

"It's structurally quite complicated because it's already signed into law, But there is a way to go about it," a senior South Korean official closely involved in the discussions said, on condition of anonymity due to the diplomatic sensitivity of the issue.
When asked about the IRA, Mr Yoon's senior economic secretary, Mr Choi Sang Mok, said neither side has yet set an agenda for the summit but could discuss the issue in light of its importance.
Mr Yoon has also been struggling to make headway on other key diplomatic and security issues, such as improving relations with Japan and enticing North Korea back to denuclearisation talks.

Mr Yoon's office said he plans to hold his first bilateral meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida in New York, though some Japanese media reports suggested the meeting may not happen as legal fights over historic disputes remain unresolved.

According to a senior official at Mr Yoon's office, the president also plans to use his speech before the UN General Assembly to reiterate the need for North Korea's denuclearisation, with Pyongyang rejecting Seoul's recent overtures and talks remaining stalled.
REUTERS

documents.title: Row over electric vehicle subsidy rules overshadows South Korean president's first US visit

sentences.content: SEOUL: South Korea's opposition to new rules governing US subsidies for electric vehicles are set to overshadow President Yoon Suk-yeol's first official trip to the United States, disrupting a recent display of alliance strength with Washington.
Yoon, who was in London for the funeral of Britain's Queen Elizabeth, departed for New York late on Monday (Sep 19) to attend the UN General Assembly.
He will fly to Canada on Thursday for the last leg of his trip before returning home on Saturday.

In New York, Yoon will hold a summit with US President Joe Biden where both leaders are expected to discuss North Korea's growing weapons threats, and mounting concerns in South Korea over the Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), signed by Biden last month.

The new law eliminates federal tax credits for electric vehicles (EVs) made outside North America, meaning companies including Hyundai Motor Co and its affiliate Kia Corp will no longer be eligible for such subsidies.

The law has sparked complaints from government officials in Seoul, who see it as a betrayal of Biden's vows to boost bilateral economic ties after South Korean companies agreed to make major investments and build factories in the United States.
Seoul officials have said the law may violate a bilateral free trade agreement, and they have asked Washington to postpone the new rules until Hyundai completes building its Georgia factory in 2025.
Yoon is likely to reiterate that request during the upcoming summit.
A number of high-level South Korean officials have been mobilised in recent weeks to relay concerns to their US counterparts and press for exemptions, though solutions are far from clear.
Trade Minister Lee Chang-yang will travel to the US this week to discuss the IRA, the ministry said on Tuesday.

US national security adviser Jake Sullivan told his South Korean counterpart Kim Sung-han early this month the IRA would bring "more pluses than minuses" to Korea but promised to review the impact of the new rules.

"It's structurally quite complicated because it's already signed into law, but there is a way to go about it," a senior South Korean official closely involved in the discussions said on condition of anonymity due to the diplomatic sensitivity of the issue.
When asked about the IRA, Yoon's senior economic secretary, Choi Sang-mok, said neither side had yet set an agenda for the summit but could discuss the issue in light of its importance.
Yoon has also been struggling to make headway on other key diplomatic and security issues such as improving relations with Japan and enticing North Korea back to denuclearisation talks.

Yoon's office said he plans to hold his first bilateral meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida in New York, though some Japanese media reports suggested the meeting may not happen as legal fights over historic disputes remain unresolved.

South Korean Foreign Minister Park Jin met with his Japanese counterpart in New York on Monday, where he asked the Japanese to work together with Seoul to resolve their differences, Park's office said in a statement.

According to a senior official at Yoon's office, the president also plans to use his speech to the UN General Assembly to reiterate the need for North Korea's denuclearisation, with Pyongyang rejecting Seoul's recent overtures and talks remaining stalled.
A diplomatic source told Reuters that Seoul and Washington are exploring how to reopen denuclearisation talks.

"Our responses to the North's recent moves have been low profile, which is intended in order to not give the level of attention they want," the source said, requesting anonymity due to the sensitivity of the issue.

"But we're sending a clear message that another nuclear test would trigger real repercussions, even harsher than the biting resolutions and measures taken after the sixth test and long-range missile launches."

silver_truth: In September 2022, tensions flared between South Korea and the United States over the recently enacted Inflation Reduction Act (IRA), which excludes South Korean-made electric vehicles (EVs) from US federal tax credits. This move, seen as discriminatory by Seoul, is argued to violate the US-South Korea Free Trade Agreement's most-favored-nation treatment clause. South Korean Prime Minister Han Duck-soo suggested seeking alternative solutions before resorting to legal actions. The issue overshadowed South Korean President Yoon Suk-yeol's first official visit to the US, which began on September 19, 2022, and included attendance at the UN General Assembly and meetings with President Joe Biden. President Yoon planned to address concerns about the IRA, including requesting a postponement of the new rules until Hyundai completes its Georgia factory in 2025. Despite high-level efforts and discussions, including mobilization of South Korean officials and a meeting between US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan and South Korean counterpart Kim Sung-han, a resolution remained elusive. The controversy also complicated broader diplomatic efforts, such as improving relations with Japan and addressing North Korea's nuclear threats, which President Yoon intended to discuss during his trip.

documents.title: 2 orang diberi suntikan vaksin Pfizer belum dicairkan, 1 dimasukkan ke hospital

sentences.content: SINGAPURA: Kementerian Kesihatan (MOH) sedang menyiasat kejadian membabitkan dua orang dewasa yang diberikan satu suntikan vaksin Pfizer yang tidak dicairkan dahulu.
Para pesakit itu dikatakan menerima suntikan tersebut di sebuah klinik ProHealth Medical Group di Hougang pada 15 September.
Menurut Penguasa Sains Kesihatan (HSA), vaksin Pfizer perlu dicairkan dengan 1.8 milimeter natrium klorida.
Seorang daripada mereka kemudian dimasukkan ke hospital selepas mengalami pening-pening dan degupan jantung yang tinggi.
Pesakit berkenaan sudahpun dibenarkan pulang.
Orang kedua kejadian ini bagaimanapun tidak melaporkan sebarang kesan sampingan.
Kinik dan doktor terbabit sudah digantung daripada Program Vaksinasi Negara sehingga diberitahu kelak.

documents.title: 2 orang diberi vaksin Covid-19 pekat di klinik Hougang, 1 terima rawatan, dikeluarkan hospital

sentences.content: DUA individu dewasa masing-masing diberi vial sepenuh vaksin Covid-19 Pfizer-BioNTech yang tidak dicair di sebuah klinik di Hougang pada 15 September lalu.

Menjawab pertanyaan The Straits Times, Kementerian Kesihatan (MOH) berkata pada Selasa (20 Sep), salah seorang daripada mereka mengalami pening kepala dan kadar degupan jantung pantas, dan telah pun dikeluarkan dari hospital.
Seorang lagi pesakit tidak melaporkan sebarang kesan teruk.
MOH berkata ia dikesan terhadap kejadian itu pada Isnin (19 Sep) dan kedua-dua individu itu menerima vaksin tersebut di ProHealth Medical Group @ Hougang.
Vial sepenuh vaksin yang tidak dicairkan itu mengandungi sebanyak lima dos.
Kementerian itu berkata: “MOH berpandang serius terhadap kejadian ini dan sedang menjalankan siasatan rapi.
"Klinik dan doktor yang telah memberi vaksin itu telah digantung daripada Program Vaksinasi Negara sehingga notis lanjut."

documents.title: Dua diberi vaksin Covid-19 yang tidak dicairkan

sentences.content: DUA individu dewasa telah diberikan suntikan vaksin Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 yang tidak dicairkan di sebuah klinik Hougang pada 15 September lalu.
Salah seorang daripada mereka telah dihantar ke hospital setelah mengalami sakit kepala dan kadar degupan jantung yang meningkat, kata Kementerian Kesihatan (MOH) kelmarin.
Pesakit itu kini sudah pulang dari hospital, lapor akhbar The Straits Times.
Pesakit yang lagi satu pula tidak melaporkan sebarang kesan.
MOH berkata mereka diberitahu tentang insiden tersebut pada 19 September, dan kedua-dua individu berkenaan telah diberikan vaksin di ProHealth Medical Group @ Hougang.
Setiap botol kecil vaksin yang belum dicairkan mengandungi sebanyak lima dos vaksin.
"MOH mengambil serius akan insiden ini dan sedang menjalani siasatan," kata MOH.
"Klinik dan doktor yang menjalankan prosedur suntikan vaksin itu telah digantung daripada Program Vaksin Kebangsaan hingga notis selanjutnya," tambah MOH.

Insiden yang serupa juga telah berlaku sebelum ini apabila seorang kakitangan di Pusat Mata Nasional Singapura (SNEC) diberikan lima dos Pfizer-BioNTech dalam satu suntikan pada 14 Januari tahun lalu.
Pusat itu kemudian berkata kejadian itu adalah kesilapan manusia apabila berlakunya salah faham antara ahli pasukan vaksinasi tersebut.
Ini berlaku kerana pekerja yang ditugaskan untuk mencairkan vaksin tersebut telah dipanggil untuk menangani tugas lain.
Menyusuli itu, seorang lagi kakitangan kemudian tersilap dan menyangka dos dalam botol kecil itu telah dicairkan dan sedia untuk suntikan.
Kesalahan itu disedari dalam beberapa minit setelah pesakit diberikan vaksin.

Dalam satu lagi kejadian, seramai 117 pesakit dan kakitangan di Poliklinik Bukit Merah diberikan sekitar satu persepuluh dos yang sepatutnya diterima antara 20 hingga 22 Oktober tahun lalu. Ini menyebabkan mereka memerlukan dos gantian.
Dalam kes ini, kesalahan itu punca silap dalam penandaan di picagari baru.

documents.title: 本地两人接种未经稀释疫苗 其中一人不适送院

sentences.content: 卫生部接获通报，指两名成人上星期四到后港杏林医药集团诊所接种了未经稀释的辉瑞疫苗。其中一人出现头痛、心跳加速等症状，送院留医四天。卫生部表示，涉事的诊所和医生已被令暂停参与全国疫苗接种计划。
57岁的林亚生和太太上个星期四一起到后港一家私人诊所施打第二支冠病追加剂。林先生打了疫苗后五到十分钟，身体开始出现不适。
“眼睛慢慢朦、慢慢朦到一半没有看见从左手到左脚会慢慢抽筋，甚至到我的脉搏跳得很快、心跳很急促我没有高血压的，一下子飙升到190多要到200。”
林亚生的女儿过后到场了解，并叫了救护车。医务人员在场向涉事医生询问详情的过程，被她用手机拍下。画面中，医生亲口承认，自己施打了过量的疫苗。
“疫苗过量了，稍微超过规定的剂量。超出多少？我们需要传达。两到三份的剂量,一次过注射。两到三份的剂量？正确的应该是一剂？应该是一剂,但现在是三倍。”
林先生说自己入院隔天开始发烧、头疼，服用了止痛药和抗生素等，直到星期天才出院。过程中他也进行了各项身体检查，目前为止未发现大碍，但仍会继续到医院复诊。
据记者了解，涉事医生是一名临时代班医生，大约两年前开始在这家诊所服务，每个月大约代班两次。出事后她已被停职。
卫生部回复本台询问时表示，另一人没有通报任何不良反应。当局严正看待这起事件，目前正在进行调查。

documents.title: 2 people given undiluted Covid-19 vaccine at Hougang clinic, 1 discharged after hospitalisation

sentences.content: SINGAPORE - Two adults were each given a full vial of the undiluted Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at a clinic in Hougang on Sept 15.
Responding to queries, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Tuesday that one of them was hospitalised after experiencing a headache and an increased heart rate, and has since been discharged.
The other patient did not report any adverse reaction.
The MOH said it was alerted to the incident on Sept 19 and that both individuals were given the vaccine at ProHealth Medical Group @ Hougang.
Each full vial of the undiluted vaccine contains five doses' worth.
Said the Health Ministry: "MOH takes a serious view of this incident and is carrying out a thorough investigation.
"The clinic and doctor who administered the vaccine have been suspended from the National Vaccination Programme until further notice."
The Straits Times has asked MOH when the hospitalised patient was discharged, and what members of the public should do if they suspect they have been given an undiluted dose of the vaccine.
There have been previous incidents of the wrong Covid-19 vaccine dosage being administered to patients.
A staff member at the Singapore National Eye Centre was given five doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in one injection on Jan 14 last year.
The centre said later that the mistake arose from human error after a lapse in communication among members of the vaccination team.
It said the worker in charge of diluting the vaccine had been called away to attend to other matters before it was done.
A second staff member had then mistakenly thought the undiluted dose in the vial was ready to be administered.
The error was discovered within minutes of the vaccination.
In another incident, 117 patients and staff at Bukit Merah Polyclinic were given around one-tenth the recommended dose between Oct 20 and Oct 22 last year, requiring replacement doses.

documents.title: Two adults given undiluted COVID-19 vaccine at Hougang clinic, one discharged after hospitalisation: MOH

sentences.content: SINGAPORE: Two adults were each given a full vial of the undiluted Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine at a clinic in Hougang, with one needing hospitalisation after experiencing headache and increased heart rate, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Tuesday (Sep 20).
Responding to CNA’s queries, the ministry said that it was alerted to the incident on Monday, which took place at a clinic under the ProHealth Medical Group on Sep 15.
“One was hospitalised after experiencing headache and increased heart rate and has since been discharged.
The other patient did not report any adverse reaction,” said MOH.
MOH said that it takes a serious view of this incident and is carrying out a thorough investigation.
“The clinic and doctor who administered the vaccine have been suspended from the National Vaccination Programme until further notice,” the ministry added.
After dilution, vials of Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine contain six doses of 0.3ml of vaccine, according to Singapore's Health Sciences Authority.
"I felt the side of my body cramping up, even to the point I felt my pulse quickening and my heart beat was increasing," said Mr Lim.
"I called my daughter for help and we waited for the ambulance to send me to the hospital."
According to Channel 8 News, the doctor involved is a locum and comes in twice a month.
She has been working at the clinic for around two years.
CNA has contacted the clinic for more information.
In a separate incident last year, MOH said it was conducting a "thorough investigation" after a 103-year-old woman was erroneously given a fourth dose of COVID-19 vaccine.
The woman was admitted to Changi General Hospital for pneumonia and hyponatremia, and was subsequently also diagnosed to have suffered a stroke.
She died the following month.
Last year, an employee at the Singapore National Eye Centre (SNEC) was wrongly administered the equivalent of five doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine due to a human error.
Senior doctors were alerted immediately and the staff was assessed and found to be well, with no adverse reaction or side effects, SNEC had said.

documents.title: Two adults given undiluted Covid-19 vaccine, one discharged after needing hospitalisation

sentences.content: SINGAPORE - Two adults were each given a full vial of the undiluted Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at a clinic in Hougang on Sept 15.
Responding to queries, the Ministry of Health (MOH) said on Tuesday that one of them was hospitalised after experiencing a headache and an increased heart rate, and has since been discharged.
The other patient did not report any adverse reaction.
The MOH said it was alerted to the incident on Sept 19 and that both individuals were given the vaccine at ProHealth Medical Group @ Hougang.
Each full vial of the undiluted vaccine contains five doses' worth.
Said the Health Ministry: "MOH takes a serious view of this incident and is carrying out a thorough investigation.
"The clinic and doctor who administered the vaccine have been suspended from the National Vaccination Programme until further notice."
The Straits Times has asked MOH when the hospitalised patient was discharged, and what members of the public should do if they suspect they have been given an undiluted dose of the vaccine.
There have been previous incidents of the wrong Covid-19 vaccine dosage being administered to patients.
A staff member at the Singapore National Eye Centre was given five doses of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine in one injection on Jan 14 last year.
The centre said later that the mistake arose from human error after a lapse in communication among members of the vaccination team.
It said the worker in charge of diluting the vaccine had been called away to attend to other matters before it was done.
A second staff member had then mistakenly thought the undiluted dose in the vial was ready to be administered.
The error was discovered within minutes of the vaccination.
In another incident, 117 patients and staff at Bukit Merah Polyclinic were given around one-tenth the recommended dose between Oct 20 and Oct 22 last year, requiring replacement doses.
In this case, the error was reportedly the result of a mistake in identifying markings on new syringes.

silver_truth: On September 15, 2022, two adults were mistakenly administered undiluted Pfizer-BioNTech Covid-19 vaccine at ProHealth Medical Group clinic in Hougang, Singapore. One of the patients, 57-year-old Lim Ya Sheng, experienced severe side effects, including headache, increased heart rate, vision problems, and muscle cramps, and was hospitalized for four days. The other patient did not report any adverse reactions. The undiluted vaccine vials contained five doses each. The Ministry of Health (MOH) was informed of the incident on September 19 and has suspended the clinic and the doctor involved from the National Vaccination Programme pending a thorough investigation. The doctor responsible was a locum with two years of intermittent service at the clinic. The MOH emphasized the seriousness of the incident, recalling past similar occurrences, including a case at the Singapore National Eye Centre in January 2021 where a staff member received five doses in one injection due to human error. Another incident involved 117 patients at Bukit Merah Polyclinic receiving only one-tenth of the recommended vaccine dose in October 2021.

documents.title: 韩国已寻国际刑警帮助 逮捕TerraUSD创办者权道亨

sentences.content: （早报讯）韩国检察官已寻求国际刑警帮助逮捕TerraUSD稳定币发行商的创始人权道亨，准备起诉权道亨违反韩国的资本市场法律。
权道亨已离开新加坡，目前下落不明。权道亨创办的Terraform Labs公司是加密货币生态系统运营商，所发行的TerraUSD稳定币和Luna加密货币在今年5月间崩盘，引发全球加密货币溃跌，令投资者损失惨重。
彭博社星期一（9月19日）报道引述检察官办公室简讯说：“检察官星期一向国际刑警组织提出请求，要求他们协助寻找目前仍然下落不明的权道亨（Do Kwon），并将他移交给韩国。”
权道亨国际刑警组织在正式收到请求帮助后，通常会发出红色通缉令（red notice），寻求全球执法部门协助展开逮捕。在发出红色通缉令之前，国际刑警组织可能需要大约一个星期的时间准备。
权道亨早前从韩国来到新加坡，他现已倒闭的Terraform Labs项目在这里有一个基地，但新加坡警方星期天（9月18日）说权道亨已经不在新加坡。权道亨否认自己在逃，虽然说首尔的检察官要求拘留他，并指他在试图避免赔偿损失。
据彭博社报道，检察官办公室早些时候说，自从权道亨去新加坡后，就有“逃跑的间接证据”，这就是为什么它发出了逮捕令。
权道亨后来在社交媒体上宣称自己并未逃跑，他没有说明自己的具体下落，但表示正在“全力配合”官方，他“没有什么可隐瞒的。”
不过韩国联合通讯社（Yonhap News Agency）报道引述检察官说，权道亨没有配合调查，并且还通过律师告诉检察官，他不打算出席接受盘问。
权道亨和其他五名Terraform Labs的员工已面对韩国警方通缉。官方可能取消他的护照，理论上这要求他在接获撤销通知后14天内回到首尔。他的新加坡工作准证即将在12月7日到期。

documents.title: Terra founder Do Kwon at risk of Interpol red notice as net tightens

sentences.content: Interpol would typically issue a red notice seeking assistance from law enforcement globally to make an arrest after receiving an official request for help.
It could take about a week before a notice is issued.
There has been "circumstantial evidence of escape" ever since he left for Singapore, and that is why an arrest warrant was issued in the first place, the prosecutors' office said earlier.
The implosion of the TerraUSD algorithmic stablecoin and its sister token Luna sparked huge losses in crypto markets, which were already reeling from tightening monetary policy.
Digital assets have yet to recover and regulators are pouring over the wreckage to see how to avoid a repeat.
In South Korea, earlier ardour for crypto is being usurped by growing disdain.
Mr Kwon tweeted over the weekend that he does not "have anything to hide" and is in "full cooperation" with officials but did not publicly reveal his location.

However, the Yonhap News Agency in a report cited prosecutors as saying that Mr Kwon is not cooperating with probes and has told investigators via an attorney that he has no intention of appearing before them for questioning.
Mr Kwon faces arrest in South Korea along with five others over the Terra unravelling.
Officials could cancel his passport, which in theory would require him to return to Seoul within 14 days of receiving the notice of revocation.
He has a Singapore employment pass that is due to expire on Dec 7 and an application for another pass is pending, government records show.
The TerraUSD stablecoin, also known as UST, crumbled from its dollar peg earlier this year and brought down the ecosystem that Mr Kwon had built.
This has triggered probes as far afield as the United States amid renewed regulatory scrutiny of stablecoins - tokens supposed to be pegged to an asset like the US dollar.

Crypto companies, meanwhile, are also waking up to the need for far stronger risk management after a series of blow-ups including Terra, the Three Arrows Capital hedge fund and crypto lender Celsius Network.

documents.title: South Korea requests Interpol's help in Terraform Labs probe

sentences.content: SEOUL: South Korean prosecutors have asked Interpol to issue a fugitive alert for the founder of Terraform Labs as they investigate a US$40 billion crash of the firm’s cryptocurrency that devastated retail investors around the world.
The Seoul Southern District Prosecutors’ Office asked Interpol on Monday (Sep 19) to circulate the “red notice” for Do Kwon across the agency’s 195 member nations to find and apprehend him.

A South Korean court recently issued arrest warrants for Kwon and five other people connected to Terraform Labs as prosecutors investigate allegations of fraud and financial crimes in relation to the implosion of its digital currencies in May.
South Korea’s Foreign Ministry said Tuesday that it’s processing the prosecutors’ request to restrict or revoke the passports of Kwon and four other suspects who are South Korean.
Interpol had not publicised the red notice for Kwon on its website as of Tuesday morning, and South Korean prosecutors say the designation may take more than a week.
Interpol describes such notices as requests to law enforcement worldwide to locate and provisionally arrest fugitives “pending extradition, surrender, or similar legal action".
Kwon's whereabouts are unknown.
South Korean authorities initially believed Kwon was in Singapore before the country's police announced last week that he wasn’t there.

Kwon, who has been accused of exaggerating the stability of his digital currencies before their collapse, insisted in a tweet on Sunday that he wasn’t on the run from any “government agency that has shown interest to communicate”.
“We are in full cooperation and we don’t have anything to hide,” Kwon said in the tweet.
The collapse of Terraform Lab’s digital currencies, TerraUSD and Luna, affected an estimated 280,000 South Korean investors while causing broader turmoil in the global cryptocurrency market.
TerraUSD was designed as a “stablecoin”.
Those are pegged to stable assets like the US dollar to prevent drastic fluctuations in prices.
However, around US$40 billion in market value was erased for the holders of TerraUSD and its floating sister currency, Luna, after the stablecoin plunged far below its US$1 peg in May.
South Korean prosecutors launched the investigation following collective complaints filed by dozens of investigators.

The Bank of Korea, South Korea’s central bank, said in a report published in June that the collapse of TerraUSD and Luna was a major factor in the global cryptocurrency market shrinking by more than 40 per cent compared to late 2021, when its market value reached over US$2.3 trillion.

silver_truth: South Korean prosecutors have requested Interpol's assistance in arresting Do Kwon, the founder of Terraform Labs, by issuing a red notice. This request follows the collapse of TerraUSD and Luna cryptocurrencies in May 2022, which caused significant financial losses globally and particularly affected 280,000 South Korean investors. The implosion of these digital currencies, previously pegged to stable assets like the US dollar, led to a broader downturn in the cryptocurrency market. Do Kwon, who left South Korea for Singapore and whose current whereabouts are unknown, is accused of violating South Korea's capital market laws and possibly committing fraud. Despite his public claims of full cooperation, prosecutors report that he has not been forthcoming with investigators and has no intention of appearing for questioning. The South Korean Foreign Ministry is also processing requests to revoke the passports of Kwon and four other suspects. His Singapore employment pass is set to expire on December 7, 2022. The incident has intensified regulatory scrutiny and prompted broader discussions on risk management within the crypto industry.

documents.title: 本地研究：沿海城市土地正下沉 海平面上升情况加剧

sentences.content: （早报讯）研究发现，全球多个人口稠密沿海城市的土地正在下沉，加剧海平面上升的影响，提高洪水风险。天然资源开采和基础设施的建设或是导致土地下陷的主因。
由南洋理工大学领导的国际研究通过干涉合成孔径雷达技术（InSAR），对全球48座人口超过500万人的沿海城市2014年至2020年的卫星图像进行分析。他们发现，全球海平面上升是因地球冰盖融化和海水增温膨胀所造成，而这些城市土地下沉的情况会使问题加剧。
南大亚洲环境学院代理院长希尔教授（Emma Hill）说：“在沿海地区土地下沉会导致海平面升高和增加洪水风险。这项研究结果将能帮助受影响的社区和政策制定者，确定哪些地区会面临严重的地面下沉风险，采取应对措施。”
这48座城市土地下沉情况各有不同，但下沉速度中位数为每年16.2毫米，最高则可达每年43毫米，全球目前海平面上升速度则为每年3.7毫米。其中，土地下沉速度最快的城市是中国天津和越南胡志明市。
研究也发现土地下沉速度最快的城市普遍集中在亚洲，尤其是东南亚地区。
研究人员接下来将通过预测土地下沉的速度以及考虑不同气候和天气的变化和敏感度，进一步开展研究。

documents.title: South-east Asian coastal cities sinking fastest, could worsen impacts of sea level rise: Study

sentences.content: SINGAPORE - South-east Asian coastal cities are sinking the fastest globally, which could amplify the impacts - such as massive flooding - of imminent sea-level rise, a recent study has found.
Sea levels are rising globally as the Earth's ice sheets melt and as warming sea water expands.
Sinking land, or land subsidence, can aggravate the problem, a team of international scientists led by the Nanyang Technological University (NTU) found.

Ms Cheryl Tay, a PhD student at NTU's Asian School of the Environment and the Earth Observatory of Singapore, noted that the many coastal cities in Asia are now centres of growth and rapid urbanisation.
This has driven up demand for groundwater extraction to meet growing water needs.

This, in turn, causes land to sink rapidly, said Ms Tay who is the first author of the research study, which was done in collaboration with the University of New Mexico, ETH Zürich and Nasa's Jet Propulsion Lab, which is managed by the California Institute of Technology.
Current global mean sea-level rise is at 3.7mm per year.
The findings were published in scientific journal Nature Sustainability in September.
In Ho Chi Minh City, the concentration of high-rise buildings in areas with weak foundations has also contributed to land subsidence.

Coupled with extreme rainfall and sea-level rise caused by climate change, land subsidence could lead to more frequent, intense and prolonged flooding for vulnerable places over the next few years, said Ms Tay.
"Floods may disrupt businesses and damage property and infrastructure.
In extreme cases, permanent flooding may affect livelihoods by damaging productive agricultural land, and force populations to move when places become uninhabitable," she added.
Climate projections have shown that the mean sea level around Singapore is projected to rise by up to 1m by 2100.
This could go up to 4m or 5m if other effects like storm surges (abnormal rise of water from storms) - which occur two to four times a year - are taken into account.

A comparison carried out across coastal cities worldwide by the researchers showed that the fastest velocities of relative local land subsidence are concentrated in Asia, especially in South-east Asia.
"This new study is important because it provides a leap forward in scientists' ability to incorporate land sinking into studies of sea-level rise.
Accurately measuring land-height change is especially important for Asia, where many large coastal cities are experiencing rapid sinking," said Prof Hill who is a co-author of the study.
To tackle these issues, governments can build up coastal defences such as sea walls, or tap nature-based solutions such as mangroves, said Ms Tay.
They should also tackle the root cause of the problem.
If extraction of resources like groundwater, oil and gas is the main cause of land subsidence for a particular city, then tailored solutions for each jurisdiction would be needed as well, she added.

Distinguished Professor Philip Liu of the National University of Singapore's Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, who was not involved in the study, pointed out that other water resources would be needed to replace groundwater extraction, and groundwater recharge plans would be needed such as by pumping used water into aquifers (an underground layer of permeable rock).
"These policies require political will," he added.

silver_truth: A recent study published on September 20, 2022, and led by Nanyang Technological University (NTU) revealed that many densely populated coastal cities worldwide are experiencing significant land subsidence, exacerbating the effects of global sea-level rise and increasing flood risks. The study utilized Interferometric Synthetic Aperture Radar (InSAR) technology to analyze satellite images of 48 coastal cities with populations over five million from 2014 to 2020. The researchers found that the median land subsidence rate is 16.2mm per year, with some cities sinking up to 43mm annually, while the global sea-level rise is currently at 3.7mm per year. The fastest-sinking cities are predominantly in Asia, especially Southeast Asia, with Ho Chi Minh City and Tianjin experiencing the highest subsidence rates. Factors such as groundwater extraction and infrastructure development are identified as primary causes of the subsidence. The findings, published in Nature Sustainability, suggest that land subsidence combined with sea-level rise could result in more frequent and severe flooding, posing significant risks to property, infrastructure, and livelihoods in vulnerable areas. The study emphasizes the need for tailored mitigation strategies, including building coastal defenses and addressing the root causes of subsidence, to manage these risks effectively.

documents.title: Wall Street ends higher after choppy trading ahead of Fed

sentences.content: NEW YORK - Wall Street's main indexes closed higher on Monday after seesawing during the session as investors wait to see how aggressively the Federal Reserve will hike interest rate hikes at this week's policy meeting.
Even more so than the Ukraine war or corporate earnings, the actions of the US central bank are driving market sentiment as traders try to position themselves for a rising interest rate environment.

The S&P 500 and the Nasdaq logged their worst weekly percentage drop since June on Friday as markets fully priced in at least a 75 basis point rise in rates at the end of Fed's Sept 20-21 policy meeting, with Fed funds futures showing a 15 per cent chance of a whopping 100 bps increase.
Unexpectedly hot August inflation data last week also raised bets on increased rate hikes down the road, with the terminal rate for US fed funds now at 4.46 per cent.

"This is all about what's going to happen on Wednesday, and what comes out of the Fed's hands on Wednesday, so I think people are just going to wait and see until then," said Josh Markman, partner at Bel Air Investment Advisors.
"We had a poor print when the CPI came in, so the Fed - who is behind the 8-ball - is now trying to get ahead of the curve and curb inflation, and that (awareness) is driving equity markets."
Focus will also be on new economic projections, due to be published alongside the Fed's policy statement at 2 p.m.
ET (1800 GMT) on Wednesday.

Worries of Fed tightening have weighed heavy on the S&P 500 this year, with a recent dire earnings report from delivery firm FedEx Corp, an inverted US Treasury yield curve and warnings from the World Bank and the IMF about an impending global economic slowdown adding to the woes.
Goldman Sachs cut its forecast for 2023 US GDP late on Friday as it projects a more aggressive Fed and sees that pushing the jobless rate higher than it previously expected.

"The Fed will continue to plough along, we'll get 75 (bps) on Wednesday, but what comes next and whether they are going to pause or not after Wednesday, that is going to be the interesting part," said Bel Air's Markman.
According to preliminary data, the S&P 500 gained 27.08 points, or 0.70 per cent, to end at 3,900.00 points, while the Nasdaq Composite gained 86.78 points, or 0.76 per cent, to 11,535.18.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 200.30 points, or 0.65 per cent, to 31,022.72.
A majority of the 11 S&P 500 sectors rose.
One exception was healthcare, which was dragged down by a fall in shares of vaccine maker Moderna Inc a day after President Joe Biden said in a CBS interview that "the pandemic is over".
Industrial stocks rebounded after a sharp drop on Friday, while banks also gained.
Tech heavyweights Apple Inc and Tesla Inc rose to provide the biggest boost to the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq.

Take-Two Interactive Software Inc closed up, having recovered from a slump earlier in the day caused by confirmation that a hacker had leaked the early footage of Grand Theft Auto VI, the next installment of the best-selling videogame.
Meanwhile, Knowbe4 Inc jumped after the cybersecurity firm said that Vista Equity Partners had offered to take it private for US$24 (S$33.79) per share, valuing the company at US$4.22 billion.
REUTERS

documents.title: Stocks drop, yields rise; investors brace for Fed, other central bank meetings

sentences.content: NEW YORK :     Global stocks fell on Tuesday while the yield on two-year U.S. Treasury notes rose to almost a 15-year high as investors prepared for the likelihood of another 75-basis-point interest rate hike from the Federal Reserve.
The Fed is set to announce its decision on Wednesday at the end of a two-day policy meeting.
Rate futures traders are pricing in an 81 per cent chance of a 75 basis point hike and a 19 per cent probability of a 100 bps of tightening.
Britain, Norway, Switzerland and Japan also have monetary policy meetings this week.
Earlier on Tuesday, Sweden's central bank raised interest rates by a larger-than-expected full percentage point to 1.75 per cent and warned of more to come over the next six months.
The U.S. two-year note, which is highly sensitive to shifts in monetary policy expectations, earlier on Tuesday hit 3.992 per cent.
The last time its yield broke above 4 per cent was Oct. 18, 2007.
Yields on the benchmark 10-year Treasury shot to 3.604 per cent before paring some gains.
They were up 8 basis points to 3.569 per cent after topping 3.5 per cent for the first time in 11 years on Monday.
The Fed and other banks are trying to take an aggressive stance to tackle inflation, but investors have also worried about the impact of higher rates on the global economy.
On Wall Street, investors were cautious of making new bets.
"Investors are just selling the Fed," said Jake Dollarhide, chief executive officer of Longbow Asset Management in Tulsa, Oklahoma.
"All of the bad that was ignored, we're getting all of that back.
People are pessimistic."
Shares of Ford Motor Co sank after the automaker said inflation-related supplier costs will run about $1 billion higher than expected in the current quarter.

The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 313.45 points, or 1.01 per cent, to 30,706.23, the S&P 500 lost 43.96 points, or 1.13 per cent, to 3,855.93 and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 109.97 points, or 0.95 per cent, to 11,425.05.
The pan-European STOXX 600 index lost 1.09 per cent and MSCI's gauge of stocks across the globe shed 0.85 per cent.
The dollar rose, trading near a two-decade high, as investors held firm on expectations of another aggressive rate hike by the Fed.
The dollar index was on track for its fifth weekly gain in six and was last up 0.5 per cent at 110.13.
It hit 110.79 this month for the first time since June 2002.
"Traders and investors are taking cover, aware that the dollar is behaving like a force of nature, and unwilling to face its wrath," said Karl Schamotta, chief market strategist at Corpay in Toronto.
The rate hike by Sweden's central bank was larger than analysts had expected, causing the Swedish crown to briefly spike against the euro and dollar.
Hikes from the Bank of England and Swiss central bank are expected on Thursday.
China's central bank kept its benchmark lending rates unchanged at a monthly fixing on Tuesday, as expected.
The Bank of Japan has shown no sign of abandoning its ultra-easy yield curve policy despite a big slide in the yen and inflation hitting its fastest pace in eight years.
The dollar was last up about 0.4 per cent against the Japanese currency.
It climbed as high as 144.99 on Sept. 7 for the first time in 24 years.
Oil prices eased as the dollar stayed strong.
Brent crude futures settled down $1.38, or 1.5 per cent, to $90.62 a barrel, while U.S. crude for October delivery ended at $84.45, down $1.28, on the day of its expiration.
The more active November contract settled down $1.42 to $83.94 a barrel.
(Additional reporting by Huw Jones in London and Gertrude Chavez-Dreyfuss; Editing by Edwina Gibbs, Will Dunham and Alison Williams)

silver_truth: On Monday, Wall Street's main indexes closed higher after fluctuating throughout the session, as investors anticipated the Federal Reserve's policy meeting on September 20-21, 2022. The market fully priced in at least a 75 basis point rate hike, with a 15 percent chance of a 100 basis point increase, following unexpectedly high August inflation data. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq saw gains, driven by tech heavyweights Apple Inc and Tesla Inc, despite healthcare sector setbacks due to a drop in Moderna Inc shares after President Joe Biden declared the pandemic over. Additionally, Take-Two Interactive Software Inc recovered from a slump caused by a hacker leak of Grand Theft Auto VI footage, and Knowbe4 Inc surged following a privatization offer from Vista Equity Partners. Goldman Sachs downgraded its 2023 US GDP forecast, expecting a more aggressive Fed.

documents.title: Apple to raise App Store prices in some countries in Europe and Asia

sentences.content: The new prices, excluding auto-renewable subscriptions, will be effective as early as Oct 5, Apple said in a blog post.
The latest price rise increases those starting prices to €1.19.
A rapid rise in inflation, interest rates and energy prices this year has hammered the yen, the euro and most emerging economy currencies.
The euro has dropped to two-decade lows this year and has been languishing around parity against the dollar for weeks.
Apart from euro zone countries, the price increases will hit Sweden and Poland in Europe; Japan, Malaysia, Pakistan, South Korea and Vietnam in Asia; and Chile in South America.
For some countries like Vietnam, the price increase was due to new regulations relating to collecting tax from consumers, Apple said.
Apple, which launched its latest generation of iPhones earlier this month, has been developing its services business to reduce dependency on its mainstay smartphones.
Revenue from Apple's services business, which includes the App Store, has been growing at a rapid pace in the last few years and now hovers around US$20 billion (S$28.2 billion) per quarter.
REUTERS

documents.title: Apple to raise App Store prices in some countries in Europe, Asia

sentences.content: Apple said on Tuesday (Sep 20) it will raise prices of apps and in-app purchases on its App Store from next month in all of the euro zone and some countries in Asia and South America.
The new prices, excluding auto-renewable subscriptions, will be effective as early as Oct 5, Apple said in a blog post.

The US tech giant periodically adjusts its prices in different regions and reduced prices for euro zone countries last year to adjust for currencies and taxes, dropping starting prices for many apps to 99 euro cents from 1.09 euros.
The latest price rise increases those starting prices to 1.19 euros.
A rapid rise in inflation, interest rates and energy prices this year has hammered the yen, the euro and most emerging economy currencies.
The euro has dropped to two-decade lows this year and has been languishing around parity against the dollar for weeks.
Apart from euro zone countries, the price increases will hit Sweden and Poland in Europe; Japan, Malaysia, Pakistan, South Korea and Vietnam in Asia; and Chile in South America.
For some countries like Vietnam, the price increase was due to new regulations relating to collecting tax from consumers, Apple said.
Apple, which launched its latest generation of iPhones earlier this month, has been developing its services business to reduce dependency on its mainstay smartphones.
Revenue from Apple's services business, which includes the App Store, has been growing at a rapid pace in the last few years and now hovers around US$20 billion per quarter.

silver_truth: On September 20, 2022, Apple announced that it will raise prices of apps and in-app purchases on its App Store starting from October 5, 2022. The price increase will affect all euro zone countries as well as Sweden, Poland, Japan, Malaysia, Pakistan, South Korea, Vietnam, and Chile. This adjustment is partly due to new regulations in countries like Vietnam, which now require tax collection from consumers. The new starting prices in the euro zone will rise from 99 euro cents to 1.19 euros. This price hike follows a period of significant economic challenges, including a rapid rise in inflation, interest rates, and energy prices, which have weakened currencies like the yen and the euro. The euro, in particular, has dropped to two-decade lows and has been trading around parity with the dollar. Apple, which recently launched its latest generation of iPhones, has been focusing on growing its services business, including the App Store, to reduce reliance on iPhone sales. This services segment has been generating about $20 billion per quarter in revenue.

documents.title: Gempa bumi kuat landa Mexico pada tarikh ‘sumpahan’ 19 September

sentences.content: MEXICO CITY: Tarikh 19 September menjadi peristiwa paling diingati di Mexico selepas satu gempa bumi kuat melanda barat negara itu, pada ulang tahun kejadian dua gegaran dahsyat yang berlaku sebelum ini.
Gempa bumi berukuran 7.7 skala Richter menyebabkan sekurang-kurangnya dua orang maut dan mencetuskan panik dalam kalangan penduduk di ratusan kilometer jauh di Mexico City.
Malah, agensi seismologi kebangsaan memaklumkan gempa bumi itu turut menggegarkan bangunan dan menyebabkan orang ramai lari bertempiaran ke jalanan di ibu negara.
Penduduk dikenali sebagai Gabriela Ramirez, 59, mengaku dia berasa trauma ketika gempa bumi baharu itu melanda lagi.
“Ketika itu, saya berasa seolah-olah akan mengalami serangan jantung.
“Kawasan ini terdedah kerana banyak bangunan rosak dalam insiden gempa bumi 2017 tidak dibaiki lagi, jadi kami bimbang ia akan ranap ketika ,” katanya.
Dilaporkan, ramai penduduk masih trauma dengan kejadian gempa bumi berlaku lima tahun lalu yang mengorbankan ratusan nyawa.

Sementara itu, Presiden Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador mengesahkan seorang maut akibat ditimpa serpihan yang terjatuh di sebuah pusat beli-belah di Manzanillo, Colima manakala seorang lagi ditemukan meninggal dunia dalam bangunan itu .
Setakat ini, beliau percaya tiada kerosakan serius yang berlaku di Mexico City.
Menurut ahli seismologi, pusat gempa terletak berhampiran pantai Pasifik, kira-kira 400 kilometer (km) barat ibu negara dan 59km ke selatan Coalcoman di negeri Michoacan.
Katanya, kedalaman pula dianggarkan 15 kilometer.
Ia merupakan gempa bumi ketiga terbesar melanda negara Amerika Latin itu pada tarikh 19 September.
Penggera gempa bumi Mexico City berbunyi kira-kira kurang daripada sejam selepas ibu negara itu mengadakan latihan kecemasan sebagai sebahagian acara bagi menandakan bencana pada 1985 dan 2017. – AFP

documents.title: Sekurang-kurang 2 maut gempa bumi kuat di Mexico

sentences.content: MEXICO CITY: Sekurang-kurang dua maut, manakala 10 lagi cedera dalam kejadian gempa bumi kuat yang melanda Mexico, kelmarin.
Pihak berkuasa memaklumkan, insiden dua mangsa terkorban berlaku di Manzanillo.
Seorang daripada mangsa berkenaan maut akibat dihempap runtuhan premis, manakala seorang lagi ditemui mati di sebuah pasar raya.
Rakaman video dikongsikan dalam media sosial, menunjukkan bumbung pasar raya itu runtuh dan menimpa tingkat atas membabitkan sebuah gimnasium, dengan orang ramai menjerit meminta pertolongan.
Malah ketua agensi perlindungan awam Mexico, Laura Velazquez, semalam memaklumkan lebih 200 bangunan turut mengalami kerosakan.
Pihak berkuasa juga melaporkan beberapa hospital di Michoacan berhampiran pusat gempa, mengalami kerosakan.
Gempa bumi berukuran 7.6 magnitud itu melanda bahagian barat Mexico, dengan kebanyakan kemusnahan berlaku di Colima dan Michoacan. - REUTERS

documents.title: Gempa Bumi Mexico Semalam, Berlaku Tepat Ulang Tahun Tragedi Sama Pada 19 Sept 1985 & 2017

sentences.content: Gempa bumi di Mexico yang berlaku 19 September semalam, berlaku tepat pada tarikh ulang tahun tragedi sama pada 19 September 1985 dan 19 September 2017.
Satu lagi kejadian gempa bumi yang berlaku di kawasan Michoacán, Mexico dengan gegaran dengan kekuatan  5.8 magnitud dan meningkatkan lagi angka kematian.
Menurut Independent, seorang daripada mangsa maut selepas dihempap bahagian hadapan kedai serbaneka di pelabuhan Pasifik Manzanillo, manakala seorang lagi ditemui mati di sebuah pusat beli-belah.
Selain itu, amaran tsunami telah dikuatkuasakan serta merta selepas bencana tersebut dan diteliti semula pada hari yang sama.
Pihak berkuasa berkata bahawa ancaman tsunami sebahagian besarnya berlalu dengan perubahan kecil aras laut sehingga 0.3 meter dan berterusan untuk beberapa jam akan datang.

Siang tadi juga, Siakap Keli turut melaporkan tentang gempa bumi di Mexico. Dalam laporan tersebut, dilaporkan sekurang-kurangnya seorang maut dan dua bangunan musnah selepas berlakunya gempa bumi bermagnitud 7.5 pada Isnin, 19 September semalam.

Sebelum gempa bumi tersebut berlaku, penggera amaran gempa telah dibunyikan ke seluruh negara sebagai tanda amaran gempa bumi yang besar bakal berlaku. Kejadian ini seakan-akan tragedi gempa bumi yang telah membunuh ribuan manusia pada tahun 1985 dan 2017.
Hari ini sepatutnya hari ulang tahun untuk bencana gempa bumi pada 1985 dan 2017
